description:
I had heard so much about Kaisen DON and was so excited to try it! I was meeting up with friends and we decided to eat here on a whim. We got here right when it opened. They informed us that they didn't have any blue Fin tuna at all today so they would be replacing the bowls with tuna with other fish. The menu is quite extensive in terms of the bowls they have and they have a rotating menu of appetizers and specials! 

I opted for the truffle salmon don and it had 6 pieces of seared salmon topped with truffle sauce. It also came with cucumbers , tamago and some seaweed on the side. The rice was nicely seasoned and when you wrapped the rice, seaweed and salmon together it was delicious! We also tried the salmon ochazuke and it was ok. The salmon was a bit salty but it was still decent. Probably wouldn't be something I order again but I would come back for all the other bowls.

This place is def not on the cheap side, but if you like good quality fish this place is a good option. Can't wait to come back to try the other dons.

Total for 3: $95
author: Stella J.

description:
This place is good, but not really good/unique enough that I'd recommend it strongly. I really wanted to try it b/c it was all over Instagram for a while, but when I went I don't really think it has anything over other sushi places. 

It's a super small space on Ocean Ave, maybe enough capacity for 15-20 people. I went on a Monday so there was no wait, but I can definitely see it being difficult to get a table on a weekend. 

There's quite a few different styles of bowls, ranging from around $15-$30 depending on what you get. I get that raw fish isn't exactly cheap, but the prices still seem a bit steep. 

It didn't help that the waiter seemed like he was always trying to upsell us on random stuff: we (party of 5) went on a Monday to get the $1 oyster special. Originally we wanted to order 10, so two per person, but the waiter said we could only order 6 or 12 even though it doesn't say anywhere on their menu that you can only order in increments like that. We also each ordered an unagi taco and he tried to convince us to order more of different types so we could try them all. No thank you... 

On the plus side though, the bowls are absolutely beautiful!
author: Melissa H.

description:
$22 for 1/4 Tray of uni that's supposed to be 7 big pieces.  Only the piece on top is a whole piece, the ones underneath are broken pieces pieces. Complete ripoff!!!!

The sushi rice are not subpar possibly cheap grains were used.  

Fish was supposed to be from japan but It sure doesn't taste like it.

Service was not good either.
author: A A.

description:
いらっしゃいませ！

Kaisen DON defines Chirashi bowls to me. Came here on a Sunday for lunch and the place was packed. Every table were seated and I see that every table had at least one Omakase Don- so I knew I had to order that! I ordered the Omakase Don along with their daily special: Truffle with Scallops. 

Omakase Don: the bowl have 12 pc of fresh sashimi and sushi rice/ comes with seaweed and wasabi/soy sauce.

Truffle with Scallops: 4 pcs of scallops topped with tobiko and truffle

Overall, the sashimi was fresh but the cut can be more generous. The concept of this place is not bad since they are mainly serving the fresh fish/bowls or hot bowls such as unagi don, salmon ochazuke don, gyu don and etc. If you like chirashi- I recommend coming here! For price wise, I do think this is an average price for chirashi bowls but I wish they would give the option to substitute some fish.
author: Sammi L.

description:
Hubby and I were looking for a kid friendly sushi place and have been seeing some pretty photos from Instagram of this place. Located in an odd location on ocean avenue, parking was easy to find (we paid for meters but later found there was ample street parking).

Omakase nigiri set is $55 so I opted for the regular nigiri set at $28. Hubby went for the omakase chirashi bowl for $30.

Food was good, quality of fish was good. Presentation was also nice. Ambiance is relaxed. We came quite late around 1:50 and was there last seating. We brought our huge stroller and our baby and felt relaxed since we went during this odd time.

Veterans and students get 10% off and also check in on yelp for a free edamame or seaweed salad.
author: Betty C.

description:
This place specializes in Chirashi bowls. I ordered the rainbow don, which came with hamachi, salmon, and tuna. The sashimi were fresh and thick. I also got the uni sampler, which came with uni from Peru (Peru produce uni??), Mexico, and Santa Barbara, 3 pierces each. SB uni won the crown. 

The waitress was extra nice to us!! 5 star service!
author: Angela T.

description:
I recently went to Kaisen Don on Ocean Ave for lunch. They specialize in Chirashi Bowls.  There are 10 Don bowls yet only one vegan option- Very Green Don- Seaweed, tofu, cucumber, & sweet tofu all over sushi rice. This is what I ordered since I am a longtime vegan of 19 years (will get my pension in veganism soon). 

Kaisen Don is a Rice Bowl which some different Sashimi are placed on Sushi Rice. Normally, it's served at Sushi restaurants & is popular for lunch. 

Chirashi, also called chirashizushi (ちらし寿司) is an interesting Japanese meal. The word "chirashi" means "scattered," so this is basically a big bowl of rice mixed with fish, vegetables, & additional ingredients of your choice. Glad they had at least one vegan option. It reminded me of unwrapped sushi in a bowl.

The Very Green Chirashi Don bowl also had pickled ginger & wasabi like is typically accompanied w/ sushi. I found it quite alright yet would love them to have at least one other vegan option such as avocado perhaps or even a more innovative vegan option.

The Very Green Don also came w/ a complimentary miso soup w/ wakame sea vegetables. I had this w/ a side of edamame-seasoned soy beans. 

Although was an interesting experience that I am glad I had would be more likely to return if they had some more interesting vegan options as aforementioned.
author: Shane S.

description:
Kaisen Don is a quaint little family-owned sushi restaurant, bringing you delicious chirashi bowls!
The Omakase Don was amazing; it had fresh & yummy pieces of sashimi, and the sashimi to rice ratio was also perfect! So even though this place is a little more on the pricey side, you get a good amount of the quality sashimi that you're paying for.
author: Kathy Y.

description:
Good Omakase Don place!

We got here around 5:30 on Sunday night and we were the first customers! We both got Omakase Don - Chef's choices 12 pieces ($28.95) which came with Uni, salmon, tuna, hamachi, tamago, fish roe, crab meats, cucumber and seaweed.

Fish was fresh and tasty but I felt that there were too much rice in a bowl. I wish there is less rice and bigger pieces of fish. Nonetheless, it was good. Uni tastes amazing! I checked in on yelp to get free edamame which was okay but good for free appetizer. Also, their tea was unexpectedly good. 

I recommend this place!
author: Clare L.

description:
A unique dinning experience. The place is small but the staff are nice. They have one menu for specials of the day and their standard menu.i tried the rainbow don and the eel don.

The eel was war and flavorful. I wish it had more sauce tho. The miso soup was nice and not salty Iike most places I have tried. The rainbow don't comes with 3 slices of salmon, 3 slices of tuna and 3 blue tail fish. I have never tried the blue tail fish, but it was fresh and nice. 

The basic concept of the place I believe is like finger food and you can make your own hand roll. I wish it had more fish, because you get more seaweed to fish, or maybe I'm suppose to cut the fish in half to make a better hand roll. But will come back to try another dish. It does get busy after 6:30.
author: Bonnie C.

description:
We came to this place to see what people have been talking about. We ordered a few items: Omakase Don, Hamachi Don and Blue Fin Tuna. Food looked good and tasted fresh for the most part. Our stomachs weren't happy afterwards so doubt that we will be coming back anytime soon. 

Pros:
Food presentation can look good on instagram.

Cons:
Way too much rice.
Not worth the price point.
Service can be improved. (It's extremely awkward and rude for them to stand over your shoulder as you try to figure out how much tip you want to leave!)

This was our personal experience and thoughts, though others may feel different. All in all, we won't be rushing back anytime soon and probably won't be recommending to friends or family.
author: Roman L.

description:
WOAHHH. BOMB AF. 

I definitely recommend everyone to give this place at try. We ordered:
Salmon Ikura Don
Kaisen Don
Scallop Lover
All were bomb and fresh! I love how they give you a side of seaweed to wrap it like a sushi roll. 

There's not many seats in there. I went on Thursday at opening time 5:30PM and it was not crowded at all. 

Also, check in and get a free edamame, which was actually really good. 

The server was super nice, parking is easy and food was good. Nothing bad to say here. Just go! :) I'm definitely coming back!
author: Darlene T.

description:
Tried them at the NorCal Night Market at Alameda County Fairgrounds this fall and they're whack. Uni was poorly presented and very skimpy portions for $17. Wasn't even the live uni from Santa Barbara.


Don't know if I will give them a try at their actual location.

Better try fine dining for my sashimi needs.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
The SO and I are absolute sushi lovers and were disappointed with our experience. The service was alright-- it was sometimes difficult to flag down a waiter/waitress as the two people working that night were chatting by the registers. 

We started with a scallop burger and blue fin sashimi. The uni in the scallop burger had a funky flavor that completely overpowered the scallops and the blue fin was very fishy and not melt-in-your-mouth tender. My main was the rainbow don and the SO got the omakase don. Both of our dons tasted very fishy and overall we felt that the fish was not very fresh. There was a decent fish to rice proportion but I ended up eating a lot of the rice to cover up the fishy flavor. 

I'm hoping that my one experience was just an off day and I'd like to try it out again in the future... but it's just a bit on the pricier end for sushi.
author: Andrea K.

description:
This place is pretty good if you're looking to satisfy your craving for sashimi and sushi! We came at around 7pm on a Saturday night and there was a small wait. The parking wasn't too bad, but it was all street parking. 

My friend and I both decided on the Rainbow Don, which cane with salmon, hamachi, and tuna. They didn't have tuna that day, so I subbed for scallops. The portions were decent, and the sashimi slices were fatty. It came with seaweed strips, which ended up being a good idea with the sashimi and rice. Of the three sashimi choices, my favorite was the salmon. The scallop has somewhat of an unusual taste, and they weren't sweet and fresh like they usually should taste. 

Prices are a little high for the chirachi here but nonetheless, a pretty good experience overall!
author: Sandra S.

description:
This place is pretty damn delicious!! If you go to omakases a lot and find yourself always just looking forward to the salmon, ikura, and uni pieces... This is the place for you. If you want variety and favor tuna, this might not have as many options for you.

Either way, omakase quality fish at very reasonable prices!

Service is iffy here. Didn't give us spoons or plates despite asking many times, so we were basically eating off a napkins. Also, they kept the door open which made the whole experience freezing cold.
author: Betty T.

description:
The wait was unbelievably long, but I guess it's normal for such a tiny restaurant with very limited seatings. For a party of 4, we waited close to an hour, and we were only second or third on the waitlist. Goodness. So you might wanna reconsider going with large parties.

Their menu is quite extensive I'd say, lots of options to choose from. Portion is very big and I had a hard time finishing my food. Sashimi was super fresh & delicious, we ended up ordering more on the side, maybe that's why I had a hard time finishing my food. Overall I'm super impressed. The price is very very reasonable for the portion and generosity in ingredients. 

The main dishes we ordered came out very inconsistently. Some was quick, some took forever to get on the table. Service was excellent though, and I think it helps that it's a very small place, haha.
author: Elle T.

description:
So I've been coming here for months and i've been behind on reviews.  When they first started the prices were reasonable, but now they are slightly higher.  Most of that time that will matter, but the food is honestly really fresh.  I love how they have a daily special menu and it changes everyday.  Which is kinda a hit or a miss.   One of the times i came here i had the salmon truffle don and was so amazing.  It was rich and fresh at the same time and once you've tried this, you'll get addicted to it.  Our at least i got addicted to it.  I also had the scallop burger which was sandwich between the seaweed with uni.  It was so delicious!! I wish i can order more of this!  There are days they have uni specials where you can order a half or full plate of uni, but watch your wallet. 

Here's are the types of Dons i had in the order i like it

Salmon truffle Don
Scallop Lover Don
Rainbow Don
Hamachi Don

I wish parking was here at night, but i guess if it was easier, i'll come her a little too much.  All the times i've been here, the service was always perfect.  I recommend this place to any lovers of chirishi or sashimi.
author: Belinda C.

description: I have been to Kaisen Don twice since they opened and I ordered the same thing both times. Their Omakse Don is pretty good with a wide variety of sashimi. My personal favorite is their salmon, uni (it can be a hit or miss, the ones I had the first time was so so: however the ones I had the second time was really tasty!) and scallop. For $34, you get all kinds of fresh seafood, I will definitely go again!
author: Ching L.

description:
Updated: Changed my rating from 4 to 5 stars as I've been there a bunch more times since my review and the food is awesome every time. Super consistent and so much fresh uni!!!!

Kaisen Don is a fantastic little chirashi joint that I have wished into existence. Chirashi is my favorite way to eat sushi.

I have been here 3-4 times. Most of the time, I order the Omakase Don and it's always creative and fresh. Last time, in addition to the medley of beautiful seafood atop a perfectly cooked bowl of rice, it came with a small slice of foie gras. Another time, it came with truffled scallops. Always comes with a spot of uni and is so delectable.

The presentation and plating of the sushi here is a clear indication that the chefs in the kitchen know what they're doing and care about their craft. Everything is so artful and pretty, it's hard to dig in!

I wish they sold a simple beer here, such as Sapporo or Orion. I'm guessing they don't have an on-sale beer and wine license.

Kaisen Don is priced fairly for the quality and quantity of food.

Keep up the good work, Kaisen!
author: Tala D.

description:
Food is great service is great 
Just like what I ate in Japan 
5 star king salmon and scallop so fresh
author: Jia W Z.

description:
We came on a Sunday to eat lunch, it's a small restaurant. The waiter was attentive to our needed and refills our tea.
We order Rainbow Bowl and Kaisen Don, Unagi Don and Sashimi. The food was delicious and looks nice. 
It's a little pricey but good experience to try .
author: Lily L.

description: Pricey but yum. Came here a while back. like a while back, but never wrote a review. Tried their Rainbow Don ($18.95) and NegiToro Don ($35.95). The rainbow don came with 3 pieces of hamachi, tuna, salmon, and cucumber over a bowl of rice. Sashimi was fresh and nicely sliced. The toro don was made with chopped up fatty tuna under ikura. Not sure I liked the chopped up toro with the rice by itself, but wrapped in the seaweed was like a negi toro handroll which was great (LOVE negi toro). They gave us about 3-4 pieces of seaweed which wasn't enough so we had to keep asking for more seaweed and that was an additional cost. We also ordered a side order of scallop sashimi which was also fresh. Overall, a very yummy meal but not completely filling. And for $20-30 for a bowl was pretty fricken pricey for the portion plus the additional costs for the seaweed is crazy. Haven't made a trip back since then but I noticed they offer more now and even have nigiri's.
author: Anissa D.

description:
Absolutely loves this place. It is a small shop so best call ahead to see how the line is like but also the staff is very attentive and friendly. Portions are great and i highly recommend the uni as it is super fresh and does not have the strong ocean taste. 

I had the Salmon Ikura bowl and everything was delicious. The salmon roe had a hint of sweetness and perfectly balanced out the meal

Would definetely come back to try the other chirashi bowls with more uni!
author: Danny F.

description:
This place is delicious and full of noms! We ordered the omakase don, the rainbow don, and the kaisen spoon. All were completely delicious. The omakase don had a good variety of fish and a great rice ratio. Super fresh and tasty. Same with the rainbow don. The kaisen spoon (which I believe has oyster, ikura, tobiko, and ponzu sauce) was really flavorful and a perfect portion size.

Service was great and the complimentary tea was surprisingly tasty. The complimentary edamame (check-in with Yelp) was decent and nothing special but nice for a small, free appetizer. 

Can't wait to go back!
author: Yanni L.

description:
LOVE this place! Fresh fish, modern and simple look, and overall a great experience! 

Why I was here // Came with a group of 6 for dinner since we had friends visiting from LA. 

Food // 
-my friend and I split the uni scallop burger // $10 // Don't be tricked, its a burger- but when they say burger, it's 2 scallops with some uni in between wrapped with seaweed. 
-Omakase Don // $28.95 // Worth getting if you are a fish lover like me! So fresh and everything was tasty and full of flavor down to the sushi rice! 

Overall // This place is pretty pricey compared to a few other places I've been to, but you are paying for quality. Everything is delicious and I would definitely love to come back! 

I think it gets busy pretty quickly, so it helps to maybe call in (not sure if they take reservations) or come closer to when they open so you can get a seat. The restaurant space is very limited.
author: Emily T.

description:
Amazing service with awesome food. Basically tried every fish in the menu and I've got to say...I was impressed. The salmon was so tasty and the tuna was perfect and as you'd expect from a good sushi restaurant.

The space is great and finding it makes you think that you've stumbled upon a hole in the wall that you'd like to keep as your own little secret.
author: Joshua F.

description:
Woah~ lcuky on trying this new omakase bento box. They look great :), love the presentation. Fish are very fresh and yummy! The Ikura nigiri is the bomb to me. I am not a big fans of ikura because i don't like them taste salty. But, their ikura is not salty at all, you can taste the fresh of the fish mixed with subtly oily but not greasy while they popping inside your mouth! Bravo! 

We went on a Sunday night and the place packed after we sat down for 10mins. Decoration is simple, but clean and neat. Could have some improvements. 

Service is great. Servers are very nice on explain the day of the specials and telling the names of fish for my omakase bento box. My tea cup never ran out of tea :)  wait time on food is average. Will recommend this place! Keep up the quality :)
author: Yong Y.

description:
I'm a huge fan of omakase and charashi... so this place was perfect! 

I came here right before closing and was able to get seated. Ordered the omakase don. Each meal comes with a miso soup. 

Food came out pretty quickly and I was in love with the presentation- especially the wasabi. I'm not a fan of wasabi so I had to pick it off :(

The bowl itself was delicious! Everything was hand-picked by the chef! My favorite was the uni, salmon and toro. The quality of everything was very fresh. 

The rice however was mushy. 

I will definitely come back regardless of parking and the rice. It's on ocean so street parking is all metered unless you find a residential spot. It's all worth the drive for the quality of fish. I left with a fully belly and smile on my face :)
author: Elaine C.

description:
New restaurant opening excitement gets the best of some of us. I'm one of the biggest offenders but I'm glad I waited on Kaisen Don.

Kaisen Don soft opened about 3 months ago in the former Rainbow T Dessert space. It's a small restaurant with seating for about 20 people so it's not a place to come rolling in with your entire posse of 10. It's ideal for solo diners and couples. No reservations.   

Kaisen Don's specialty is chirashi with about 10 variations. For those squeamish about raw fish, they have dons with cooked proteins: chicken teriyaki, unagi, chashu, and beef curry. Each order comes with a complimentary bowl of miso soup. Currently, they don't have a liquor license. 

If you see a particular item on their Yelp page that you want, call before visiting. I saw a pic of the shaved ankimo but they didn't have it and the girl at the table in back of me wanted negitoro but they didn't have that either. 

Note to the owner, there's a small discrepancy on your Yelp page. It says, to mention Yelp to get 20% off but the grand opening check-in offer is 10% off. 

Last week, I had some time to kill because of street cleaning in my area so I figured it was the perfect time to visit Kaisen Don.

I ordered the Omakase Don ($28.95): http://bit.ly/2H8jKfF. The fish and seafood toppings will vary daily and based on seasonality. 

On the day, I visited my Omakase don was topped with Mirugai (geoduck), Hamachi (yellowtail), Ikura (salmon roe), Uni (sea urchin), Hotate (scallop), Sake (salmon torched), Amaebi (raw shrimp, no head), Kani w/ its brain (crab leg w/ torched brain), and Tamago (sweet egg omelet). For the value driven folks, the cuts of fish (~12 slices) are thicker than usual for a chirashi. Small sheets of nori are provided so you can make mini hand rolls. 

(+) Good variety with some premium offerings like mirugai and uni. Remember I said, I was glad I waited on visiting Kaisen Don? During their soft opening, the toppings for the omakase don were run-of-the-mill fish like maguro, hamachi, and sake. Didn't see premium offerings. 

(+) Everything was super fresh with my favorite being the perfectly sweet and briny Santa Barbara uni. So good. 

(-) Knife skills could be improved. Several slices didn't have clean edges (i.e. amaebi). 

(-) While the sushi rice was a good temperature and texture, it was underseasoned and plain. 

(-) The wasabi was awful quality (dry, crumbly texture). Yes, it has their cute embossed fish logo but I hope the owner looks into using higher quality wasabi to match their fish.  

Service was polite and friendly. I was their first customer of the day and it took about 20 minutes for my order. 

Minimalist dining area with wooden tables and metal chairs. I enjoyed the 80s and 90s music they were playing. 

Looking at their pictures and their reviews for the past couple of months, it does seem Kaisen Don has some consistency issues and/or still trying to figure things out but I wouldn't be opposed to returning. Their raw fish is good quality and that's what's most important to me.

When I'm having a raw craving and don't want to spend $$$ on a nice sushi dinner or deal with the madness at Amami, Kaisen Don will do just fine.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: My new favorite place to eat. The special salmon sashimi topped with truffle was heavenly! The place is small, but we did not feel crammed. We had a large party (7 adults and two kids), and we did not feel rushed at all. Definitely a neighborhood find to share with friends and family!
author: Angelia H.

description:
Service = A
Food = B
Decor/Ambiance = non existent

Kaizen Spoon = $7. 1 bite of oyster, uni, and tobiko. It was a nice combination of sweet uni and salty oyster.

Rainbow bowl = $19. 3 pieces each of tuna, salmon, and hamachi. Pretty fresh, but none of the fish was amazing or had a wow factor

Kaizen bowl = $28. Chef's choice. Best part was the uni.

I do like that they give seaweed strips to make your own handrolls. Service was really quick and the waiter was really attentive to our tea refills & anything else we needed.

Overall, we thought it was overpriced for the quantity and quality of food served.
author: Jessica C.

description:
This place is delicious! It's kind of everything I was looking for in a sushi bowl! Fresh fish, decent price and generous portions. I came here on a week day around 7pm and there was a bit of a line, but not bad. The place is super small, so if you don't want to wait come off hours.

We ordered:
Uni Spoons: Fresh and delicious in one spoonful! Uni was so fresh and loved the combination with the sauce!
Scallop Bowl: If you are a scallops fan, this is your type of bowl. They gave lots of scallops and salmon roe all over it, so good with the rice!
Omakase Bowl: RECOMMEND! If you want a bit of everything, this hits the spot. The amount of fish they give is generous and each bite was pure happiness to my tummy.

Overall, I would come here again! I wish they had a Uni bowl, but they just opened not long ago, so maybe someday ;) 

P.S every bowl comes with a miso soup! #winning
author: Natalie L.

description:
I really wanted to love this place but the stomach pain that I had almost immediately after I finished my bowl made me feel otherwise. I ordered the Kaisen Don, which had scallops, crab legs, and ikura. Two of the four scallops that I had in my bowl tasted funny - kind of a stinging/sour feeling in my mouth. I disregarded it the first time, hoping that the feeling was just from the wasabi, but when I got the same taste after not using any wasabi, I knew it was the scallop. Either way, I still finished my bowl (big mistake), but I had a pretty intense stomachache after I left. Luckily, it didn't last the whole night. Maybe I just got unlucky with a few bad pieces of scallop, since, judging from reviews this doesn't happen often. 

On the other hand, my boyfriend ordered the Rainbow Don, which I also tried a bit of. His bowl was great, the fish tasted fresh and we both really liked how they give you strips of seaweed on the side to make your own sushi roll. Every bowl also comes with complimentary miso soup. They also have hot bowls with chasiu or unagi, etc. 

I would say that the chirashi bowls are on the pricer side, around $20-30 per bowl, with the hot bowls a little cheaper. I might be willing to go back to try their other options, but definitely won't be getting any of the scallops!
author: Cecille W.

description:
Came here early on Saturday night and was able to grab a table right away. 

I got the Omakase bowl and my husband got the Rainbow Bowl, along with an Uni/Oyster spoon. 

The service was friendly, with one person running the front of the house. The place is pretty small, seats 20 max. 

The fish was really fresh,but I left feeling unsatisfied, and my husband still hungry. 

The 20% opening discount made the trip worthwhile, but it would be nice to see some additions to the menu like appetizers. I believe they are a few months away from getting their liquor license, until then, no sake with your fish.
author: Mimi T.

description:
The 20% off your order for their soft opening was definitely a draw in! They didn't specify for how long, but I'd go before it ends!

Their décor was incredibly minimalistic and set a very clean atmosphere. I liked their concept on how to eat the bowls. Not sure if that's the traditional way but I've never seen it before and fell in love. You're supposed to wrap bite sized rolls with the contents of your bowl into the little seaweed pieces that are provided with your dish. I opted for the Kaisen Don #2 ($18.95) but I wish I had gotten the Scallop Lover ($16.95) instead. I don't think the crab legs were worth the extra $2 and the scallop was so clean and fresh, the Scallop Lover would have been a better option for me. 

Overall, I liked Kaisen Don and the 20% off was definitely a steal.
author: Annie N.

description:
A pretty decent place to get your Chirashi don fix. The portions are perfect. Not too big and not too small. They're also really generous with the rice. Miso soup was complimentary. However, the prices are a little high. 

Place is pretty small and it threw me off when there was a very strong fish smell as soon as I walked in. My jean jacket still has the smell of fish stuck to it. 

My favorite item that was ordered would be the uni scallop burger. The uni scallop burger has black truffle sauce stuffed inside. Each burger is $10. This item isn't listed on the actual menu but is written on a very small chalkboard near the cash register. If it wasn't for yelp, I wouldn't have known this item existed. 

Other items ordered were the Kaisen spoon (oyster topped with uni), salmon ikura don, and chashu don. 

Salmon ikura don was about $20. It was good but I don't think it was worth $20!? Luckily, there was a 10% discount for the yelp check in!
author: Bonnie T.

description: Ordered Chashu Don, Hamachi Taco, Salmon Truffle Don. Free edamame with check-in. Service was very attentive and courteous. Food was tasty but portions were small for the price. I was about 80% full after eating the Chashu Don and Hamachi Taco.
author: Cathrin P C.

description:
I'm always in the mood for sashimi so I knew I had to give Kaisen Don a try when I saw it pop up on Yelp! We were lucky enough to not have to wait at all- I could imagine that the wait times will change once people start hearing about this place. 

Here's what I liked:
(+) Fresh sashimi - everything in our omakase don were de-lish especially the crab!
(+) They obviously put thought into the presentation of the donburi so that they are gram ready!
(+) 20% off during their grand opening!
(+) UNI UNI UNI

Here's what I thought could use more work:
(-) The service was not terrible at all, but our waitress was a bit flustered and unorganized.
(-) The 1/2 tray of uni that we ordered didn't really come out in a half tray. It seems to be a smaller portion than what I'm used to, but it could very well be just perception because of the presentation. 

I think I'd definitely come back for more especially while they are still offering 20% off!
author: Tiffany U.

description: Stellar food. Beautiful presentation! Friendly service. Ample street parking. Limited seating. Clean bathroom
author: Linda L.

description:
A hidden gem for good donburi AND UNI!  Came here for a later lunch on a Saturday (1pm-ish).

Venue / Service: on the smaller side, the biggest table probably seats 4 people and fits probably no more than 20 people.  B/c the kitchen is small, food does take a bit on the longer side, but not long enough that you start to get impatient.

Food: in general, the donburis are well portioned, in fact larger than I've seen at most places.  Enough protein vs. rice and bowl sizes are good enough to fill the stomach of a hungry guy.
-- Santa Barbara Uni / Half Tray (~$30) - came here mainly for this since we love uni.  A half tray is around 5 pieces, which are placed on slices of cucumber and served with wasabi and pieces of nori.  We basically placed pieces of uni in the nori with a bit of wasabi, which I think was the best way to enjoy the taste cleanly.  Uni was pretty fresh and sweet (being from Santa Barbara); definitely worth the trip for!

-- Gyu Don (thin beef, onion, tamago)($12.95) - to supplement the uni, I ordered one of these.  The tamago was tasty, even if it looked more like cheese.  The beef was nice and tender and they give you a decent amount vs. rice.  Wish there were more veggies / onions, but the taste was pretty good.

My date had the Unagi Don (BBQ eel, seaweed, pickle)($15.95), which was also quite tasty.  A bit too much of the sauce on it, but the eel was nicely cooked and was a pretty big piece.

All in all, we weren't disappointed after driving out of SF just to try their uni and the donburis.  Price was a bit high, but I think my date and I would make a trip out again here.
author: Audrey H.

description:
Don't get me wrong, I'm not a sushi hater.  I actually prefer fish over meat because its low in carbs and high in protein.  That equates to less time in the gym to burn off those calories.  

Unfortunately, the portion of rice to fish was excessive.  I would say a majority of the bowl was rice.  I ordered the kaisen don #1 and there were a few pieces of tamago, salmon, and ikura.  Honestly I thought, the omakase don my sister ordered was a better deal.  Especially with the 20% off.  

The yelp says their fish come from the Tsukiji market which is a well known fish trade port in Japan.  However, the preparation of their fish could be improved.  I felt like the texture wasn't firm enough and on the mushier side.  I was also very surprised to find a piece of bone that was still inside one of the yellow tail pieces.  It's fortunate that I didn't swallow the piece whole...
author: Derek L.

description:
3.5 Stars

Long story short

Seating is not great for large parties
Portion of rice is copious however inconsistency in cooking was a let down
Presentation of the fish was good and enjoyed the variety in the Omakase Don 

Overall Thoughts

If they can step up their rice game I could see myself coming back to try their other bowls
author: Eddie W.

description:
Fresh fish, good miso, service was relatively quick, not too busy as it seems to be a soft opening. 

However, it's a bit too expensive averaging around $20 or more for a bowl, seems a bit high. For that price, I was expecting a bigger bowl...at least five more rice for the impression of a bigger bowl.
author: Long C.

description:
Thanks to @yelpsf for the recommendation. I have been wanting to try this new hot spot out and finally made the worthy Foodie Adventure thanks to @derjaymarz for visiting all the way from Germany and hungry SF Foodie @epumas.eats and @da.dan.chan for the company. This Omakase Don took me back to the day I went to Tsukiji Fish Market in Ginza. I went with homie, @kenikophoto, met a dope couple that shared their company and eduacated us about delicious fresh Uni.

Go and try this delicious bowl and utilize that soft opening 20% off.  

Larry the owner, opened up the door and me and my friend waited outside patiently. First one there I asked if he was the owner and he told us he was. It was nice to meet him and that now I know that there's a way more delicious spot than the other fish bowls nearby the area. Cost a little more but if you want to taste fish similar to what they have in Japan, GO HERE you will not be upset.
author: Jray M.

description:
First off, if you've been to tsukiji market in Tokyo then you'd really appreciate this restaurant... I wanna say it's the first of its kind in the Bay Area since I haven't seen anything similar around the area. But it's pretty much different selections of chirashi (fish over rice), exactly like how they serve it in tsukiji. For this reason alone, it gets a higher rating from me...

As far as my experience here is concerned, I think there's definitely some improvements to be had, but they're still in the soft opening stages so guess I'll give them some slack... the main issue that I saw on my visit was the lack of efficiency/staff (tables were not being cleaned, which meant longer wait time). Other than that, service was very good.

Food wise... the taste and freshness was there. I ordered the ikura/uni don and the ikura tasted exceptional! It was very well marinated with a balance of sweetness and saltiness, probably one of the best I've tasted (even compared to Japan). The uni was also very fresh with no fishy-ness whatsoever. BUT....... even though it tasted good, there was a slight issue with it. The amount of ikura WAS NOT the same as advertised... and for $30, I'd expect the rice to be fully covered. Although, there is still the 20% soft opening discount, so I guess I won't complain too much :p

Overall verdict... 

I'll definitely be back for more! Cause the other stuff looks good too.
author: Marco M.

description:
Super tiny place, prices are a little high, but absolutely delicious. I came in 40 minutes before they were closing for a table of two and had a very short wait.

We got the salmon ikura don and rainbow don to share. The bowls are very similar, except the rainbow don has a variety of fish instead of just salmon. If you like raw fish, I'd recommend the rainbow don instead of the salmon ikura don because it has more slices of fish (unless you love roe then get salmon). All the fish were fresh and the rice was very addicting. It comes with a side of seaweed so we made our own mini sushi wraps.

Service was great, but it should be since the restaurant isn't that big. Overall, I will definitely be back despite the high prices.
author: Julian Y.

description:
Decent place with a good concept! Not many places offer a variety of don options. This place has just the right amount! Menu is clean but not overwhelming. 

In terms of value, I've definitely had other chirashi bowls I find more worth it but this place isn't bad at all. Everything was fresh and delicious but portion was a bit small for guys especially.

The complimentary miso soup was very bland. It was like drinking hot water :/ I had the Kaisen Don, it was good! I saw on other yelp posts that there seems to be a Kaisen Don #1 & #2 but the waitress said there's only one Kaisen Don so that was slightly confusing.

I really wanted to try the appetizers (kaisen spoon $7/ea. & scallop burger $10/ea.) but they just seem a bit too pricy for the quantity.

Definitely worth trying but I'm not 100% on coming back because of the price.
author: Mandy H.

description:
Fresh sashimi. 20% off for their grand opening still going on this month... for how much longer, I do not know. This place is small with only a few tables. Prices are a little on the pricier side but you pay for quality freshness. Delicious but might not be as filling for some. I certainly wanted more sashimi as I neared my last piece! But my wallet didn't want to comply. They accept credit cards and they will bring around an iPad with a Square reader to take your payment. The music playing in the restaurant is also connected to the iPad though so when your payment is going through, the music will suddenly stop as it gets awkwardly silent.

RAINBOW DON
Three slices each for salmon, hamachi, and tuna with a big bowl of rice underneath. You get some seaweed on the side and also it comes with a bowl of miso soup.
author: Diana C.

description:
I love chirashi bowls so when I found out that this place opened up near my neighborhood I was so stoked to check it out. I went with the omakase don because why wouldn't you want a little bit of everything?! It came with salmon, tuna, yellowtail, octopus, salmon roe, and shrimp. AND TO MY SURPRISE, uni and tamago! I didn't even want to touch my bowl because of how beautiful it was. Each piece of fish and seafood was so fresh! 

For a new business, these guys know what they're doing. Service was great, I didn't feel rushed at all even though we stayed past their lunch hours (...sorry! But thank you again!!) I now found a new spot for when I have my cravings!
author: Christene M.

description:
FYI- Their prices have been going down! So stop by to see rather than look at the menus we Yelpers uploaded :)

Happy to see a newcomer on Ocean Ave, and with a pretty and clean aesthetic. I've gotten the Rainbow don to go and while they were out of yellowtail, the woman behind the counter let me know that she subbed in some scallop and ikura - a pleasant surprise!

I love chirashi bowls, and while this might not be a weekly meal for me, I'll definitely make it a point to bring my starving boyfriend here. The price point is pretty solid considering the quality and amount of raw fish. Comparable to even ordering the same amount of nigiri (raw fish on top of a little mound of rice), actually. The bowls come with a standard miso soup and some seaweed.

Service can be a little slow in the evenings if just one person is working, but they've been really friendly. You would think that it would be more crowded considering the yoga and gym crowd around the corner...

They're still working the little kinks out, but I'm digging their logo and food. Give them a try!
author: Colleen M.

description:
Don bowls done right! Great new chirashi spot to fill a SF void. The bud and I came here on a Saturday for a noon lunch. Zero wait. Only one other table filled in the restaurant. Parking was a bit of a nightmare bc this spot is pretty close to the 24hr fitness on Ocean. 

Anyways, within 30mins of our meal, the entire spot was packed. In fact, by the time we were leaving, there was at least 3 groups waiting to be seated. So come hungry, come early!

As for the food choices, there's just about a dozen to choose from. I was mostly disappointed bc I didn't see an option with uni + fish. I misread a previous post that said their uni specials are wknights only. AH. But otherwise, my friend and I both stuck with the Rainbow Don option, which was delish. The fresh salmon, hamachi, tuna sashimi pieces were massive and came with a refreshing slice of lemon each, on top of a bed of pebbled sushi rice. A TON of rice. We felt wasteful bc we couldn't even get through half of our rice!

With 20% off during their soft opening, it made for a great (more) budget friendly lunch option. I'd come back again on a wknight to try the uni special! 4 stars :)
author: Jennifer L.

description: For a specialized chirashi bowl place in a quiet part of Ocean Ave, the food is fantastic, fresh, and portion is generous. Quality is consistent, price is fair, and I am so happy they are here to bring different kinds of Uni to this neighborhood! I ordered take out as well as have been in the joint with friends, and I always feel satisfied. Love it!
author: DC H.

description:
A hidden don spot! (Dons are short for donburi which are Japanese rice bowls!)

Kaisen Don is a new donburi restaurant. They have a wide menu; from curry dons, to unagi dons, and even chirashi dons! (fresh fish dons). This looked like a cool new place to try!

My friend and I came at around 7pm on a Monday night. Parking here is atrocious so just a heads up! The restaurant is tiny and most of the tables were filled. Luckily there was some open spaces so my friend and I did not have to wait!

My friend and I both ordered the Rainbow Don (Hamachi (yellow tail), Ikura Roe, Tuna, Salmon, cucumbers, sushi rice, ginger, and wasabi). When you order a don, you get a complimentary miso soup! 

The miso soup was a bit on a salty side for me, but beyond that it was good classic miso soup.
The Rainbow don here is the main attraction for me. First and foremost the presentation of the don cannot be understated. It looked gorgeous and the various colors and textures made it pleasing to the eye. Overall, I liked this dish a lot! The portion size was definitely small, but the quality of the fish and overall ingredients were good. The fishes definitely all had a good amount of fat for me and the taste of each individual fish could be distinguished. However, I definitely think the sushi rice could have been a bit more flavored for me. I didn't realize it was sushi rice until 1/4 of the way in.

Overall while this was an expensive experience it was one to remember. The service here was also very good and friendly, it is something I really appreciated! A lot of the dons are rather expensive, but they have a ton of dons here to try and the rainbow don was definitely something I enjoyed!
author: Anthony Y.

description:
It smelled quite fishy when I walked in so I was skeptical about the quality. 

The price is very hefty for what you get. Everything was very mediocre for the value. Would I come again? Probably not. The bowls are just cram packed with rice and just had a few sashimi slices. 

10bucks got me like 4 thin sliced scallops that if you put together was probably barely one scallop.

A hand roll wasn't even rolled. It was literally a seaweed on display with some rice on top. I think it was aiming for aesthetics but it was way too novelty.
author: Allan W.

description:
The bf & I were pretty excited to try this place based on the reviews & the close distance from his home, but we were sadly disappointed by the quality & price.

FOOD:
- Omakase Don $29 
While this don offers a h-u-g-e variety of fish & etc, the quality doesn't deliver. The squid & scallop were also extremely disappointing - leaving a gross aftertaste in both of our mouths. The rice was ok.
- Rainbow Don $19
We ordered this based off of yelp reviews but don't be fooled. I didn't know a rainbow only had 3 colors.. but there were only 3 sashimi options offered with this & only 1 out of the 3 actually tasted decent.

ETC:
- Parking may be difficult, as it's on a very busy street.

Given that it seems like a fairly new restaurant, we might consider coming back.. or not. We'll see!
author: Rachel Y.

description:
Very fresh fish especially Uni, worth very penny. 
The restaurant was very small with one waiter but service was very attentive.
author: S T.

description: The salmon ochazuka bowl is warm and delicious. The sashimi is very fresh, especially the salmon. The omakase bowl is ok, if you check in this restaurant, you will get a bowl of edamame for free. At lunch time, every customer will get a miso soup for free.
author: Vanessa Z.

description: Small humble shop, super fresh fish prepared in small batches. Omakase bento is the one everyone should opt for. It includes select dishes of the day as well as new flavors only select to them. I really appreciated how fresh each piece of fish was and how the flavor profiles of each slice. Even in the bowl that we had, most bowls from other places seem to be one tone, but not there!
author: Owie P.

description: Came for dinner on Friday and it was soooo good.  I noticed some changes since the soft opening.  Food was served in beautiful matching Japanese ceramic and the menu has evolved with photos, which speaks a thousand words.  If you love fresh fish, then you are at the right place.  The fish is so fresh, you can taste the difference and well worth the price, for the freshness and the way the food is presented.  The bowls come with miso soup and seaweed, so you can customize your wraps to eat. They have daily specials too.  We ordered the Hokkaido uni, which tasted so sweet and rich.  Nice cozy place, which only seats 20 people, so best to come early, to ensure a seat and to find street parking.
author: Elaine Y.

description: This place is awesome! Quality is like being in Japan! I frequent Japan 2-3 x a year and this place is my savior for my cravings. Monday they had $1 oysters, and the salmon truffle bowl is a must!
author: Lanai T.

description:
Kaisen Don is an excellent new Donburi shop near Daly City. Portions are just the right size for a meal - not too big, not too small and the fish is very fresh. They're quite small so seating can be limited, but since the neighborhood is not too busy you shouldn't expect too much of a wait if one at all. 

I like how they put the menu together with basically one concept: chirashi but a variety of different combinations for you to choose from. It's quick, it's easy, and it's yummy.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Came here with the recommendation from a good friend. We showed up around 8pm on a tuesday night and was seated promptly. The restaurant is small, somewhat hidden amongst all the businesses on Ocean Avenue. It's right across the street from 24 hour as a marker. Probably not an ideal location for a big party. 

Overall, we would say that the meal was enjoyable. As someone that loves fresh fish and Chirashi style meals, I had really high hopes that Kaisen Don was going to live up to the hype.

Both the BF and I ordered the Omakase Don which looked beautiful, but for what it was was, I can't say that we were blown away by the quality nor the quantity of the bowl. Like another yelper mentioned, the rice has too much vinegar and the rice to fish ratio was poor. I know quality fresh seafood is pricey, and I expected that, but overall I can't say that the meal was memorable. I've definitely had more enjoyable chirashi dons at other places for better pricing and quality. 

Unfortunately, there was a very strong fish odor when you walk into the restaurant. I know, i know, it's a fresh sushi/sashimi restaurant, of course, it will smell like fish. However, the smell was overwhelming and a bit offputting. 

I believe the best thing we had that night was the scallop truffle burger. It tasted great..but I can't justify the price in the future. 

Would I come back? Probably if i felt like splurging. Would I recommend it to a friend? I'm not sure. Like I said, unfortunately, the meal was not memorable for me. What I do praise is the owner's passion for wanting to bring something he loved from Japan to here. The execution was a good homage to the bowls that we would eat in Japan and it's a great addition to Ocean. 

All in all, it's a local/private business that is worth checking out if you're okay with spending a little more on your meal for seafood.
author: Diane T.

description:
Delish and legit dons!

You are definitely tasting quality with every bite of fresh sashimi, sweet roe, and perfectly cooked sushi rice. 

The pricing is a bit steep, but you do get what you pay for! Omakase Don was $29 which has a variety of everything, including uni. I personally thought it was way too much food. I prefer to get the Hamachi Don ($16.95) which is smaller but oh-so delicious with healthy slices of hamachi and topped with a quarter bowl of sweet roe. 

I also tried the Scallop Burger ($9.99) which consisted of two pieces of scallops sandwiching uni and truffle butter. This was decent but wouldn't get again. 

The restaurant is pretty small with only 5 tables or so. I wouldn't bring a huge group as there is only one "big" table that can fit up to 6 people.
author: Kathleen N.

description:
Definitely not the best chirashi I've had, but not the worst either.

My friend and I wanted to check out Kaisen Don after seeing it on Instragram.  We found seats no problem on a Monday night at 7pm, but the restaurant is tiny, with only room for about 15 people.  I'd anticipate a wait on the weekend just because of the size of the restaurant.  

They had scallops on special that night, so we went with one omakase don and a scallop don.  I have to say, the scallops were super fresh and sweet.  So good!  The rest of the fish was pretty good too, but I think I was expecting a little more in the omakase after paying $30.  Some other people mentioned this, but what took away from the dishes was the under-seasoned sushi rice and the addition of raw daikon in the don.  Both were bland and I avoided eating the daikon entirely.  It was more like it was put there to take up space in the bowl.  The wasabi was also really low quality, which took away from the taste of the fish.  A lot of what makes a restaurant great is in the details.

Service is really great though, the waitress must have refilled our tea cups 10 times!  I'd be willing to come back if they did something about their wasabi and rice.

Tips and Tricks
-The K line will take you to almost right in front of the restaurant, pretty convenient!
-Almost everything is served as a donburi, not much variety in the menu
author: Jessica L.

description:
Came here Thursday evening and there wasn't a line which is great. We ordered Omakase don and Negitoro don and a Hamachi Kama. 

I was expecting the Omakase don like the ones I see on pictures with crab but I have the baby octopus instead, and I thought for that price, the baby octopus shouldn't be in that bowl and there should be a bit more quantity to the bowl. However, the quality of the other fishes has wowed me enough, so I give it a 5 star. 

For the Negitoro don, it was the most expensive item on the menu, and we expected pieces of blue fin tuna toro bedded on top of sushi rice, but instead it was minced toro tuna. We thought chopping up the toro would be such a waste of a good fish, but surprisingly, the minced tuna rice and salmon roe and roasted seaweed flakes were a perfect combination, it was so good that we finished that bowl in just a sec. 

I also have to make a comment on their Salmon roe. The only time I had Salmon roe that is not fishy was the time when I travel in Japan. But this place rocks that Salmon Roe. IT IS NOT FISHY AT ALL. 

Lastly, the Hamachi kama was cooked perfectly. The portion is big and the meat are so tender and juicy. We usually will order Hamachi kama whenever we dine at Japanese restaurant, but never had any Hamachi Kama with this quality and size. 

We will definitely come back!
author: Cherry S.

description:
There aren't many chirashi places in San Francisco, so I was excited to see this place in my recommendations. TL;DR Despite the positive//negative reviews, try this place for yourself because you won't regret it!

It's a small restaurant with seating for only ~20 people so the wait may be longer than usual. I went in around 8:30 on a Friday and waited till 8:55 before getting a table for 2.

We ordered an Omakase Don ($26.95) and a Gyu Don (13.95). The Omakase Don had various types of fish, but it was your basics (tuna, salmon, hamachi, etc.). The Gyu Don is pretty much a beef sukiyaki bowl. The fish is fresh and sukiyaki is well made, not too salty and not too sweet. However, there is a problem with both of these bowls - too much rice! There was so much rice in the Omakase Don that half of the bowl was still full. There was a lot of filler on the Omakase Don - I truly hope they decide to add more fish on it, then the $26.95 would justify it.

Overall, I had a great experience here, the employees are friendly and pretty hardworking. I think that only two people work here and it can get overwhelming for them. If you're the manager, help them out and hire one more person!
author: Nicholas H.

description:
Had the sashimi omakase Don (I think). Very tasty and well decorated. Good service and not too busy for lunch on a weekday. 

Need to stop by again. :)
author: ben c.

description:
Ok the first 2 times I came I was really happy. Order the Kaisen Don & uni special on Tuesday. Was really happy both times and excited that there was an actually good don place close to my home. 

Unfortunately the 3rd time we came back order the kaisen don again and was truly disappointed. They skimped on the rice, didn't include some of the fish I got the first 2x, fish quality wasn't consistent with the 2 previous visits. 

I'm gonna give it one more try hopefully they redeem themselves because it was really good and convenient.
author: Rio J.

description:
It's exactly what you would expect: a specialized menu with about 15 choices of various dons/chirashi. 

I ordered the rainbow don, it had hamachi, salmon, and tuna. It was on a bed of rice and came with shaved radish, some cucumber slices, and wasabi/ginger. It was really straight forward. I really liked the rice actually. (When you walk in, it smells of vinegar rice.) Their fish is fresh and it was a good enough portion to feel satisfied. I broke up some of my fish chunks, eating them in half piece for better portioning with rice and nori. 

I would say that their service is good. Wendy was our server and she was very friendly. I'm just confused on whether this is a place where you go up to the counter to pay... After our bowls were taken, the check never came. Our server came later with an ipad to ring us up, but to me, it's just an awkward paying experience because what if I wanted to spilt the bill differently or something. I'm not sure, next time I'll just be more direct. 

I'll definitely be back. I liked it a lot.
author: Tina Y.

description:
The fish was fresh. The price and the RICE was not! 

Ugh, the rice was seriously disappointing. Enough that I wouldn't return and enough that I won't be recommending Kaisen Don. Rice is extremely important in Japanese cuisine, especially for rice bowls. The rice here isn't cooked or seasoned the right way. I understand there's more than one way to season rice, but Kaisen Don's rice isn't authentic. Their method for cooking rice and for seasoning rice aren't on par with other Japanese restaurants that fall into the same price point. 

I've been to Japan and other Japanese restaurants located in the nation, and I don't touch rice unless it's good. Hence, it's very disappointing that the only options they have here are rice bowls with disappointing rice.
author: Debbie T.

description:
First place I wanted to try coming back home was Kaisen Don. Thank you Yelp. 

20% off Chirashi bowls? YES.
This means that the most bang for your buck is to order the most expensive one. And that's what I did. I got the Omakase Don $28.95 which included Tako, Hamachi, Salmon, Ikura, Tuna, Ebi, AND Uni. The Uni wasn't specified in the menu or picture, but I got it anyways. Merry Christmas to me! 

The restaurant is small and limited to small parties. The menu is simple as it comes with different kinds of dons (donburis). Although not stated in the menu, it comes with a bowl of mushroom miso soup which was a delightful start to the meal. 

The bowl takes quite a while to make as I'm sure they prepare it fresh. 
 
My thoughts, if you've been to Grubbies, I find this place awfully resembling of it. The cute fish logo reminds me of their fish soy packets and the bowls were kinda similar in style. 

The fish tasted fresh, but immediately entering place  you can smell the fishiness. The pieces of fish are of good size but some pieces were oddly sliced. The fish was good, but something was missing as the texture was non-existent. Salmon was bland, toro was lean, and ebi was skimpy looking. Uni was fine ... but lacked sweetness. Lastly, the rice was too unportional sticky. Fortunately the good thing was the tamago, ikura, and tako. 

+Tamago was sweet and firm
+Ikura was like tiny dragon balls that popped nicely in your mouth
+Tako was tender
++Seaweed pieces were great as it provided extra flavor and texture

I've had better for cheaper. The fact it is located near SF State, I'm sure it'll attract the millenials, me being one of them. 20% discount is a good deal and that's probably the only reason I'll be coming back along with Super Cue right there.

****For another review of this place: My brother Derek L.
author: Fiona L.

description: Every time I've eaten here the staff has been super nice and the fish is incredible. So fresh! So glad we got another great restaurant in the neighborhood.
author: Justin W.

description:
I think I found this place through yelp's new businesses and then followed up with looking through pictures of their amazing donburis. Four stars for their creativity and simplicity in opening a place that only serves donburis. Don't expect anything more but don't expect anything less either.

A "don" is short for Donburi which is basically meat and rice in Japanese food language. They offer around 15 different dons - ranging from the Omakase don to cooked items like Teriyaki Chicken don. 

For three girls, we ordered:
Omakase don - features a range of different sashimi at two to three pieces each: uni, hamachi, tamago, salmon, toro, tuna. 
Rainbow don: another mix of sashimi, very similar to the omakase don
Scallop Lover don: scallop sashimi with Ikura 
Unagi don: unagi with sauce over rice

We came in on a Saturday night, 630pm for three, about a 20 min wait. Their fish overall is fresh, better end of Japanese restaurants. They give you enough fish a lot of rice and ikura. We ended up taking the seaweed pieces they gave us to make Ikura nigiris. 

They are still in their soft opening phase. Very apparent with their furnishing and this place is small. Imagine a newly painted apartment living room with open kitchen split in half for you to only dine in the living room portion. Would not recommend a party of more than four. Not cozy at all, pretty bare but comfortable enough for dinner. 

Overall, I would return because I do want to try their Uni special which is only available Tues-Thurs. Otherwise, it would be a go to place for take out donburis! I would not wait more than thirty mins for this place. Just get the take out instead if you have a rainy day.
author: Miffy Y.

description:
I've had good experiences with Chirashi bowls, and I was excited to try this place since it's close by and there aren't many places like it in the neighborhood. 

The place was cute! I liked the hip wooden decor and minimalistic branding. It is small, but we got there before noon, so there was still lots of seating. 

We got the Kaisen Don #1 and the Rainbow Don. We waited a bit for our food to come out, but it wasn't too bad. And, we had some miso soup to sip on while we waited. I was pleasantly surprised when we got our food. The bowls were so beautiful, especially the Kaisen Don!  Each piece of fish seemed meticulously place. I loved the little wasabi stamped with the store logo. 

They give you really crisp seaweed on the side to go with your bowl. I liked how the wasabi on the milder side, not as nose-tingling as other places,. The fish and shrimp was very fresh, not fishy at all. And it was a fair amount of fish for what we paid for. The flavor of the sushi rice was good, not overpowering, and the texture was nice and sticky. The amount of rice was typical for a Chirashi bowl. I wasn't a huge fan of the tamago as it was too sweet for me. I typically like it saltier, but it was nice and firm. It was a good amount of food for me, so I was pretty full by the end of the meal. 

The owner was very nice and came by to refill our cups whenever we ran out of tea. 

Overall, it was a great experience, and I would definitely come back again. They mentioned they would be adding more stuff to the menu in January! I'm excited to try the new stuff!
author: Christine L.

description:
Ordered 4 chirashi bowls for take out last night and they looked nothing like the pictures or what are served at the restaurant. 
There was so much rice and so little fish. It also look like we were given end parts of the fish that they would not served to dine in customers. One of the bowl which had a strong bad tuna smell to it had to be discarded. We asked to add ikura in one of the bowl and they added a tea spoon of ikura to the bowl after charging us an extra $5 for it. The waiter forgot half of of our order also and we had to ask them for the seaweed that were supposed to come with the order. 
Very disappointing for the takeout and do not recommend it. Also the staff are very disorganized and forgetful. 
The price of their bowl even with their current 20% off is too high considering the quality and quantity of fish you get.
author: Sty S.

description: I typically don't eat a ton of seafood like this, but I really enjoyed this place.  I ordered the Omokase Don which allowed me to try a little bit of everything (tuna, salmon, tobiko, sweet egg, shrimp, and hamachi).  The fish tasted extremely fresh with a hint of sweetness in the flavor. Not sure if this is a thing based on my lack of familiarity with seafood.  The dining room was also quaint and the staff was very nice and attentive.  I would definite come here again with some of my fish loving friends.
author: Mitch T.

description:
I almost don't want to review them because I don't want it to be hella packed next time I come...but it's amazing! Presentation is on point. Everything is clearly prepared with precision and care. And the flavors are equally amazing. 

Tried the uni taco, unagi don, and truffle salmon don. All delicious. Chirashi bowls served with nori strips.

I'll be back.
author: Gina R.

description:
Not bad!

Came here with a party of 4 a little after they had opened for the evening and we were seated right away. I ordered the scallop don, while he ordered the unagi don. There were a few bowls that they were out of, so be prepared with 2nd and 3rd choices when you order.

All of our orders came with miso soup to start. My scallops tasted fresh and there was enough protein to satisfy me. The cooked donburi bowls take a bit longer to prepare (obviously), and they don't bring everything out at the same time. Service was good. Overall, would come back.
author: Leslie C.

description: A fun casual chirashi spot! They give a very nice portion in the Rainbow Bowl and the Kaisen don. All the sashimi is very fresh. This place is surprisingly not crowded considering how small it is, but maybe its the location. Overall, fair price for quality sashimi bowl.
author: Nikita K.

description:
Raw fish on top of rice is the best! Kaisen is about a 10 minute drive from my house although it is in an area where it's difficult to find street parking. I recommend that one either take the muni or uber. 
Since they are brand new, they had a 20% off grand opening special which I took advantage of. I got their rainbow bowl. I haven't gotten their uni bowl but I definitely will in the future, hopefully.
The bowl was good, with thick cuts of raw fish. There was lots of rice underneath after I finished the rice. 
The restaurant itself is tiny. It's much better for take out. Pricey but then again, it's SF and raw fish.
author: Michelle R.

description:
Yelp said I might like this place. On Yelp's suggestion, I was feeling a bit whimsical and had a huge craving for sushi so I decided spur of the moment to check this place out. It's kind of far if you live centrally in San Francisco, but it's right off the public transportation line so it's not a terrible trek.

For their soft opening, 20% off was an awesome deal. We got the omakase don and rainbow don. It comes with miso soup and tea gratuit. The service was friendly and it wasn't difficult to get a seat at 6pm (nor was it hard for anyone who walked in after us to up until 7pm). One thing I loved was the amount of fish that you get on top of the chirashi bowl - Kaisen Don is by far one of the more generous places. As for improvements: the rice (as others have mentioned) and quality of wasabi are in need of help. I'm kind of picky about my rice, but I think it could have used more seasoning or "sushi rice flavor". The menu pictures also don't exactly match what you get... For example in the omakase don, no uni is pictured, but you do get uni in your bowl. A simple difference like that could entirely change my decision if I want a bowl or not! Granted that they've only been open a month and are still working a few things out, I think they have the potential to build out a strong following of Yelpers and diners soon. :)
author: Joanne Y.

description: This was such an unexpected find! So glad that my sisters and I decided to try this place. This restaurant specializes in Kaisen don's (hence the name of the restaurant). Kaisen dons are basically rice bowls with different types of sashimi on top. I got the rainbow don, but I switched out the tuna for more salmon sashimi. The quality of the fish was top notch! I could tell the fish was super clean and fresh. There wasn't any fishy smell or taste at all. Would definitely recommend trying out this hidden gem!
author: Eunice C.

description: A very small restaurant but has a marvelous japanese sushi and Donburi meals to offer. We went here on Mondays because we always go for the oysters happy hour which means $1 per oyster.  We definitely fall in love with Kaisen Don and it is very close to our place. Can't wait again for this coming Monday!
author: Salie E.

description: It's pretty fresh good uni, I will come back again just for the "half tray UNI"  No place like this that you can have a whole tray of uni!
author: Heidy S.

description:
Saw this place listed as a new business and that's just a huge flag for me to go try it out. I LOVE chirashi bowls and to see that they combined an omakase experience into one bowl, I just really wanted to try the concept. 

It is currently still soft opening and a Monday night, so the restaurant was empty except for the lady and I. I like the small feel as it does help me feel like the food isn't mass produced to meet the demand, but carefully crafted to impress a small audience at a time. 

I ordered an Omakase Bowl and was impressed by the presentation. See picture for what I really mean as words are kind of hard to explain! The one gripe I have about and -1 Star for is its kind of hard to eat. The wasabi is right smack in the middle, the ginger is bundled to the side, radish(?) shreds are supporting the fish, but the rice is almost impossible to get to. We also ordered the spoons, which were alright, and I have mixed feelings about them being $7/spoon. One thing for sure is the quality of the seafood and the time and effort put into each dish.
author: Tyler D.

description:
Quality is good but I feel that the portion is small.

The pictures are decieving when it comes to portion, I honestly feel that they cheap out on rice,  but the quality of the fish is actually good. I honestly think this place is overhyped and overpriced  but if I'm craving for a kaisen (seafood) don, I will be getting it from here since it's around my neighborhood.
author: Toni Rose M.

description: the best ikura I have in US！Sweet and umami！very nice service！five stars for this place. I will come back again even Im in east coast！flight straight for Kaisen Don！
author: Yuri Z.

description:
Really fresh!  You pay a little more than usual, but it's worth it! 

The unagi don, best one I have had in the city.
author: Deb L.

description:
Very fresh seafood at a cute, modern place on Ocean Ave. Delicious Scallop Don! (2$ off for being the daily special, Check the board outside.) Complimentary tea and miso soup (not too salty, with a nice and light
 flavor) Friendly Staff. They also do to-go orders
author: Laurie C.

description:
My partner and I stopped by here when we were craving something less saucy then the million poke places. The fish here is amazing, and incredibly fresh- especially the salmon, and it looks like the bowls are seasonal. The fish slices are hefty, you definitely get your money's worth. Tea and miso soup and served, and our waiter was highly attentive. They also gave you nori pieces!! 

There aren't any don places here, (Japanese dish over rice) so it's exciting to have one with such fresh fish nearby. Definitely recommend stopping by, definitely coming back. 

The one thing I also really appreciated was the authenticity of the place. We just came back from japan, but we felt like they definitely got it right. It would be nice if in the future they could offer half portions. I was so stuffed I felt like I couldn't move. Worth it, but half portion would have been great too. Good luck!
author: Kimly D.

description: I love their Hamachi Kama. The reason I took away one star is because there are some bugs or flies circling around our table all the time we ate there, which isn't too pleasant.
author: Jane A.

description:
I had high hope for this place for from what I saw and read, it seemed to be an authentic place for some good Chirashi. The portion is tiny compared to the price. I ordered an appetizer called scallop burger, that is $15 for 2... which when they delivered it was literally 2 pieces of scallops... and the chef's choice was $30 dollars... pricey for the food... fish was fresh and nicely cut, but the portion is tiny.
With$45 per person you can get some decent nigiri.
author: Shirley Z.

description: Small portion, expensive $, average taste. I decided to try because it is a new business and close to home. They should offer a soup and salad with the don to make it a meal. I understand the operating cost in SF is high but for the price of almost $20/person for just a don with rice and a small portion of fish, I rather go to those poke places.
author: Sharon H.

description:
Good service, and grand opening 20%off
I like their salmon don and scallops don
Their sashimi are fresh 
Everything was perfect!!
author: Khloe M.

description:
I really wanted to write a great review from this place bc a friend of mine and my brother heard great things about this place but even before I started eatting, I already had a sour taste in my mouth. 

I get sushi, sashimi and chirashi bowls all the time. What makes a Japanese place more unique or better than the others? Not that much. Its just gotta have yummy fresh fish and great service.

So I came to celebrate my father with an outting with my family. I got there early and asked about the Nigiri Omasake that was not on the menu bc i saw it on Instagram as a new dish and knew my dad would l-o-v-e it. So I asked and they told me they only serve it at lunch bc at dinner they are busy and understaffed. No problem. Fair. It was dinner time and there was like only 5 people in the whole restaurant. Fair, maybe it does get busy. 10min later, he serves the table next to me that "Nigiri Omasake" that I had asked about that is "only served at lunch". Funny I thought, so I looked at him and gestured and had a confused look on my face and he said "Oh they are for Instagram". Wow. I have a foodie account on Instagram too and was planning to post about it but I came here to have dinner with my family too. But because I am not for Instagram, I can't order it? It would be totally fine if it was a standard rule but just minutes after I was told it was not serve-able, its served right by me? When I had seen it on Instagram so I came here?

Really horrible experience. Food was just fine. Service aside from the above wasn't memorable. But I really didn't appreciate the customer experience as a whole. When we were eatting, nobody else walked in and it was just as empty as when I had asked about the "Nigiri Omasake". I would have appreciated it if he had offered to serve it after I clearly was not happy. Didn't attempt to try and make up my displeasure. 

If all that didn't didn't happen, I would have given 3 stars bc this place isn't that special and I have other Japanese places to go to that have better service and food in general. 

Gotta work on your customer service.
author: Jessica L.

description:
My friends and I all ordered the same bowl, Rainbow Don. 

Price: $$
You will end up paying about the same, if not more, for a 9 piece sashimi assortment. (and it usually does not come with rice and miso soup) For some people, one bowl might not be filling enough.

Fish: Good Quality
We expected red tuna to come with our order. We were shocked when we got chu toro instead. I'm not sure if we just lucky. The other photos I see on Yelp are red tuna. They gave us SO MUCH RICE. The rice to fish proportion didn't seem right.  

Venue: Small
The restaurant itself is small so please go earlier and avoid dinner rush hours.

Service: Good
The server was very attentive. She actually recommended that we all order something different so we can have variety. 

I highly recommend that you give this place a try. The quality and service are both good. The only downside is that you might walk out hungry with just one bowl.
author: Autumn L.

description:
Wow I'm so full and my wallet has so much money in it after this meal.

Just, like, no...no. Service is passive. Food is a joke. Just don't come here?
author: Christopher X.

description:
So good
The restaurant is clean and food is fresh.
They have the logo on the wasabi   very cute.
author: Peggy L.

description: Fresh seafood but i think a bit overpriced. Very small portions. Japanese rice could be better.
author: Jasmine And Wibby F.

description:
This is one of the hidden new gems on Ocean Ave. Fresh, high quality sashimi for relatively affordable price is a rarity and this place is that.

It's a small place with a small staff so service and wait times reflect that nature. It also smells strongly like the ocean (brininess). 

For those trying this place for the first time, I suggest going hard and trying their omakase don. If you're not a fan of raw fish, their unagi don is made to order and delicious (it can be too much of the same texture/taste for some due to the quantity you're getting). The salmon ochazuke is also a good Asian comfort dish, it's very remeniscent of porridge; something I would order if I was sick. 

All in all, I think this place is worth trying and has become one of my go to places for good sashimi that isn't a Michelin star restaurant. Plus, you can order a goddamn tray of uni here, please.
author: Eric L.

description: Nice addition to the neighborhood, considering there are only a couple other Japanese spots (Yama & Sakesan). Quaint inside, lowkey has a fishy smell. Pretty good quality but prices are on the higher side. Would return for a chirashi fix, they are open for lunch Monday thru Saturday!
author: Siri E.

description:
Needless to say. This place is so "overpriced" for what it's worth. I went in with the expectation that it's going to be overpriced, but figured that I'd give it a try due to the positive reviews.

After eating there and $32 later, I realized that it was a complete waste of money. True that they use very good and fresh ingredients. But I could get similar if not the same quality but cheaper at many of the city's decent Japanese restaurants. 

In addition, some reviews say that they serve generous portions here. That is totally not true. My sashimi was very small. 

I will not recommend this place to anyone or come back myself. Also, don't know how a place like this can survive in today's competitive market.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Came here couple times, twice on Monday to try the oysters, they have $1 oyster on Monday and love the special menu, hamachi taco and crab legs, very fresh fish, will come back more often
author: Mable L.

description:
Kaisen Don is a great addition to Ocean Ave. The Don menu is divided logically between sashimi and non-sashimi selections. They have high-end delicacies and staple items on the menu. The uni and scallop specials are incredible and make their way into the don dishes. 

Street parking is not difficult. Small venue, great for lunch and dinner. 

Aviento 5 estrellas. Buen provecho!
author: R S.

description: A-ok. Got the Kaisen Don and the daily special of the uni and hotate don. The scallop and ikura was decently fresh. The rice was a disappointment, mushy and bland. Added ebi, so not worth it, $5 for a tiny piece of shrimp. Total after tax for 2 don plus the ebi was $43. Each don came with a bowl of watery miso soup. Went on a Saturday and it was not buzzing, plenty of parking too. Come to get your don fix, but don't expect too much.
author: Erica B.

description: The first two days to eat oysters and strip hamburger, no woman boss, the first and second visits to the boss are very fresh, this time did not see, the belt and oysters feel not fresh, my friend eat fat cattle back three times in the stomach, hope to do more effort and care in food.
author: 珊珊

description:
