Skip this place. The restaurant isn't ventilated so it smells fishy when you walk in. The bowls are really small, sashimi are ok but I wouldn't call it fresh. What bothered me was that the wasabi and ginger were in the bowl, and that the rice isn't sushi rice but it's not plain rice either. Also, the server was trying to organize the chopsticks and napkins and dropped them on the floor, and then placed them on the table. Um... am I wiping my mouth with a napkin that fell on the floor??? 

Anyways, maybe it's better if they do a pick up only, I was pretty disappointed in the experience.
author: S Y.

description:
First impression reminds me of Tokyo. A small, authentic, clean restaurant with a very polite host greeting you with a smile. I saw the reviews on Yelp and I thought, I knew, I really hoped it would be the best sushi I had in a long time. 

I ordered the Uni, Ikura Don. I was pleased by the freshness and presentation but disappointed with the quantity. Paying $29 for 4 Uni which 3 pieces were very small did not compare to the pictures on the menu or the Yelp reviews. The Ikura was plentiful and lots of rice but for a premium price I expectedly least 6 pieces of Uni and large pieces like the photos. 

The Miso soup was barely warm. Very disappointed in the soup. The hot tea was good. 

I want to return to try other dishes but there are so many places I feel are better deals and better prices I likely won't return. 

Only a 3 star rating because of price and quantity did not meet my expectations. 

Service was good and the place is clean. But the 6 table restaurant only seats 16 people. 

I've seen hole in the wall restaurants grow into huge successes by exceeding all areas of importance. Quality, price, and quantity. Service is 4th on my list but everyone is different. Not talking about bad service just service is last to quality of food, price for value, and quantity so you feel good about a deal. 

I don't feel like I got a good deal this time.
author: G S.

description: It's nice to have a chirashi bowl restaurant open on Ocean Ave - a welcome addition to the loads of Chinese restaurants along the street.  Both restaurant size and menu are small, but the quality and value of the meal are worth it.  I thought for the price (they were running a 20% off promotion at the time we visited), the amount of fish in each bowl was pretty generous.  The cheesecake we had for dessert was quite tasty too.
author: David C.

description: Hotaruika! That firefly squid!!!! I just can't believe almost all dons are under $30! And in good quality! What made me happy the most was that yuzukoshou (citrus pepper mix) garnishment was on top of hamachi. I've never seen hipster kick-ass trick like that in SF! Job well done!!! Woot woot!
author: Toshimi N.

description:
This is more of a 1.5 star review. Anyone with a 3+ star review has either:
-never had a decent chirashi bowl
-has a diet consisting of Old Town chirashi (see above)
-was high while eating

Why?

I know its 20% off, but is it also 20% off the portions as well? I ordered the Kaisen Don #1, but at full price, I would not. Its about $19 for the bowl. At that price, I'm expecting an extra slice of salmon or 2 and one more sweet shrimp. Also leave the lemon out, it just doesn't go with the bowl.

As for the taste, its alright, but not worth $19-alright. The rice was plain, where's the seasoning/rice vinegar? Hello? I mean it's just rice but the rice vinegar makes a big difference especially when paired with raw fish. 

Also, get rid of the lemon, the lemon rubs onto the fish and partially masks the freshness the taste/freshness of the fish. Unless you're using shitty fish, get rid of the shitty lemon. Once you use rice vinegar, the lemon will be too overbearing anyways. Or put it to the side if you insist putting lemon in the bowl.

Another, the thickness of the cut of the fish. The salmon were basically in blocks in my don (there's much photographic proof that this is so on this yelp page). Just look at the photos, they're goddamn 2-match-box-combined sized chunks.
The reason why a lot of chirashi places have thinner slices is so people can easily wrap their fish around their rice and dip it in sauce. But instead, you have a block of salmon which you eat separately from the rice. 

The radish. 
The goddamn pile of #radish.
Sure it makes it instagrammable or whatever, but nobody eats that much radish with chirashi. If you insist on leaving that much radish then at least place it over a leaf/seaweed/lettuce so people can pull out all the radish in one fell swoop instead of picking at it to remove it.

Just from these small but important details you can tell these guys were just like "Oh hey let's just open a Chirashi place because it's easy to make the food and it's popular" without much regard on how Chirashi is supposed to be made.

One more thing to pick at: "bringing Tsukiji's food CULTURE". So is the fish from Tsukiji or are you guys only talking about the food culture in which they have fresh fish everyday? Because this place is literally just fish over rice and not how chirashi actually is.

I think this place can be a lot better. I think SF needs more chirashi places like this one BUT BETTER. I hope my review has given you some insight what to expect (as a potential customer) and what can be improved (as the owner). I'm hoping when I give this place a 2nd chance in a month or so, it'll become a place I can bring my friends without feeling embarrassed.
author: Chris C.

description:
I'm definitely a fan. I came here to check out the place since it seemed really promising (and also 20% off during their soft opening is such a good deal). 

I was warned in prior yelp reviews about the fish to rice portion, but I didn't think too much of it. When does anyone not complain about how much rice you get? It did seem like a lot of rice, but I didn't think it was excessive. 

Since it was a weeknight, they had their uni trays and we got the 1/2 tray. It was delicious and creamy. I was pretty happy with the portion as well. At first, it looked like five pieces on five cucumbers with a sprinkle of ikura, but it was about three pieces on top of each other. I also got the omakase don and it was well worth it. It had salmon, tako, tamago, ikura, uni, scallops, hamachi. Everything was really fresh tasting and I was pretty content with the dish. I was pretty stuffed at the end of it. 

Their menu prices changed to be a bit lower. We received three menus with the pricing and then one menu with the changed pricing. I'm sure they are still adjusting in the early stages. The omakase was $28.95 originally but was lowered to $24.95. I thought the prices were pretty reasonable for what you get. 

I'd come back whenever I need a chirashi fix.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
I am leaning towards more of a 3-3.5 stars.
We have ordered twice from them now, and I get the same thing, but it's been inconsistent with what they place on top. So maybe they are figuring out what works best?

The sushi rice the first time was decent but the second time, it was bland, tasted like normal rice not sushi rice.

the only solid constant was the sashimi, always tastes fresh and nicely cut, so that is great.
They also give a good amount of ikura, (happy husband)

my rainbow don- first time I had tamago, and maybe one slice less of each sashimi? second time, I was like "oh yay they added more!..but wait! where is my tamago?"
so I'm not sure which is the correct version, I think it's the second one, since the recent pictures look like what I got.
Both versions were fine, but when you are expecting something and don't get it, it can be disappointing. 
we also were given seaweed packets the second time, which was very nice!

my only other irk was that we ordered over the phone, but it still took a while to get our meal....and they didn't seem that busy? Ah well, like my husband said, they could have had LOTS of to-go orders...

we'll still definitely come by again for their fresh chirashi bowls...a little too much rice in my opinion though...
worth it with their 20%
author: Christine M.

description: W O W the quality of the fish here is superb. If you're a hamachi lover like me, I would totally recommend the rainbow don! The hamachi melted in my mouth and was super fresh. The salmon didn't really have that glistening effect that I usually see on fatty salmon but the quality of it was pretty ok. I think the lemon helped make it more tasteful. Ehh I would probably skip the seaweed they give on a little tray. It was pretty stale and hard to bite into. I tried to bite a small piece of it, but it got stuck on my teeth LOL. The rice was pretty good too! Idk if they only put rice vinegar to it but it was pretty tasty with the fish. My friend's order didn't have enough fish for hers :/ I think she only had like 6 pieces compared to mine? I forgot her order! Either way, I think people should check this place out before the 20% off soft opening coupon expires because this place is pretty expensive! I do like how they have a sashimi bowl place here that I wouldn't need to go to downtown and try the Grubbies. Other than that, I don't think I would come back unless I really REALLY want to treat myself out!
author: Sarah F.

description: Really fresh and good quality fish!!  We have a party of six and everyone loves his/her order!
author: Felicis W.

description:
This review is based on my visit of their soft opening on Saturday, November 11 and a follow-up visit. 

The seafood has been noticeably fresh during my visits here and service has been excellent. Larry and John are super friendly and accommodating. 

I'm hoping they can maintain their quality and somewhat reasonable prices. Looking forward to my next visit!
author: Michael K.

description:
I think this place could be truly special with some minor tweaks. 

1. More seaweed papers to eat the bowls with. Making your own sushi is kind of the big appeal here, otherwise it's just a pretty Chicago bowl. 

2. Less vinegar in the rice. I went here during the soft open and the rice had wayyyy too much vinegar. It simply over powered the fish and roe, nearly ruining the whole dish. 

Other than that, the food was delicious and fun to grub.
author: Nathan N.

description:
Their bowls are fresh, and their server is super sweet. 
It's quiet and simple inside. 
No BS, just good fresh fish.
author: Faye-Denise L.

description: Hahahaha ... this little cozy place is a definite must try. Great selection of fish and great flavors of rice bowls. Specials are prevalent everyday and have amazing balance between flavors. I will come again and try more bowls in the future.
author: Patrick L.

description: I was expecting a lot so I was kinda disappointed. After reading some reviews I thought I found the best. The price was pretty high considering the area. Ive eaten in Japan town and was satisfied for less. The fish were pretty fresh, good presentation but kind of bland tasting. The server was very polite and the wait time for the food was very good. I might be back after they have been open much longer.
author: Jolens V.

description:
Really fresh fish, delicious and simple chirashi and rice bowls during their soft opening. It's not high brow, but sashimi you can eat on a daily basis. Though, maybe weekly cause you don't want to be like that guy that pulled a 5 ft tape worm out of his stomach cause if his daily sashimi habit... 

We had the uni scallop bowl and the chef's omakase bowl. Both so good. Simple, fresh, and underrated. Cute lunch spot. I'll be coming back again soon! They're planning to add a bunch of side dishes, too. Excited to try them all!!
author: Steph M.

description: This place is really, really good.  The fish is incredibly fresh and the rice perfectly prepared.  Comparable to some of the chirashi bowls I have had in Japan.  Price is extremely reasonable (especially for the quality), and the service is really kind.  For the amazing omakase bowl, we paid the same price as we would for mediocre sushi rolls from a commodity sushi restaurant.
author: Daniel W.

description: This place has quality fish, love the ikura but very skimpy on the fish for the price even with the 20% discount. Usually the bowl would be covered with no rice showing but this place doesn't even cover the small bowl with fish so value not so that great. Lunch is not a affordable meal more of a splurge lunch. With all the students around they have to have more affordable dons.
author: Whitney N.

description: This place is absolutely delicious. I can't wait to come back and try the chef choice. The price is very reasonable for the quality you get. Don't expect to get full if you can eat a lot. I was very satisfied...
author: Aylee G.

description:
15$ for a scallop ikura don,are you kidding?
You can easily spend that much at any cheap Asian around and get some mediocre food.
This is delicious!!!!
author: Ganesh B.

description: The staff was super nice, the decor is adorable and perfect for date night! The Christmas tree had tiny little don pictures on it! We ordered our food Togo I got the #1 and it was delicious! The eggs were sweet and the salmon and shrimp was so fresh! Will definitely be coming back!!
author: Jenni A.

description:
Pluses are:
* Super fresh fish - plus the ikura was glistening and popped in your mouth! Also, slices are good sized (1/4" thick). 
* Wide selection of bowls - if you aren't into fresh fish, you should go somewhere else, this is Kaisen Don meaning "sashimi fish on rice"! If they were a true Kaisen Don as their name suggests, then this would be true. However they do offer beef, salmon or beef curry on rice among other things.
* Friendly owner
* Continued 20% off discount after soft opening

Cons:
* Weird/small table layout - I realize they are still working things out, but after 1 month they need to get this squared. Waiting families had no where to sit, but stand against the wall?!? When we were there, the layout was a definite fire hazard and non-handicapped compliant.
* Unusually long wait time - we had to wait about 25 minutes after ordering to get our bowls. Fish put on rice. That is essentially what the bowls are. Felt awkward when people waiting for a table are almost right in your face.
* Cost - borderline high. The 20% discount helped, but I think that people should take photos with some reference in it like a phone or something. *I shouldn't talk as I didn't do it either.* In the photos the bowls "seem" big and packed with goodies. Again, the fish is super fresh. But we actually left a little hungry.

Lastly, I hope that this restaurant tries to understand the minute differences that true Japanese restaurants reflect. A huge plus they already have is the quality of fish. However, omakase means to "let the chef decide". It does not mean "put a little of each thing on the menu". "Omakase" is meant for the best of the best that day, so what it includes will also change day to day. As a Japanese customer, it saddened me.
author: Mark M.

description: The ingredients here are amazing. For the price tag, they have the best Hokkaido uni, Hokkaido scallop, and Ikura.
author: Edward H.

description: This is definitely our favorite chirashi don (Japanese seafood bowl) place! It's so conveniently located in our neighborhood and the interior is very sleek and clean. We tried their Scallop, Ikura and Uni Don, Salmon Green Tea Don and Hamachi, Uni Don! Ingredients are so fresh and yummy that will definitely bring us back! Highly recommend this place to all sushi lovers!
author: Big Day Service S.

description:
The first thing I want to get out of the way is that if you were expecting a replica of Tsukiji Market or a more authentic Japanese chirashi don you're going to be missing one big thing: the rice. 

Normally I wouldn't point out something that seems to inconsequential but since it's a location that leans marketing heavily on being inspired by Tsukiji, I was expecting it to feature the more heavily vinegared rice from Japan.  

Without it, even though the ingredients were buttery and soft, you get the distinct impression that it feels there's too much rice. Let me be clear though: I don't actually think there is too much rice! Especially if you get a bowl with ikura, there's enough to go around. But WITHOUT a more flavored rice this is the impression you get, you can see this in other reviews as well.

Some places mitigate this with sauces, like a poke bowl or similarly inspired chirashi dons. I get the impression they included the seaweed paper / nori to mitigate it here without adding sauces. Kaisen does try to be authentic in the bowl, you get just the fish / sea food, but without the strongly vinegar laden rice you get in Japan to compliment it, it's going to fall short of expectations. Those who've been to Japan will know it's the rice being bland, those who've never been to Japan misattribute the problem to being too much rice when there's the right amount, it's just unflavored.

But at the end of the day, it's not bad and it's in my neighborhood and I always appreciate more options. The 20% off during soft opening till the 17th makes it a good deal, plus the customer service is very friendly and attentive. The decor is trendy and clean. This review is probably a 3.5 star, but I want small businesses to succeed so I round up instead of down.

They were told me I could request more vinegar next time i order so I'll try that and keep praying that some place is bold enough to offer the good rice.
author: Susan L.

description: Came here on a Friday night with three others, and since they didn't do reservations, we were expecting a wait. Upon arrival, we almost missed the entire restaurant because it is a very small shop in the middle of the block fitting 20 people maximum. Small spot, but surprisingly no wait. We got there and were seated within 5 minutes. There was only 1 server working the whole floor, but she was friendly. They're known for their chirashi bowl so we ordered three: two Rainbow Don and one Salmon Scallop Don. The bowls were a good size and served with a side of seaweed for you to DIY. The rice was not bad, and the perfect amount to place with each piece of fish on seaweed. Fish and seaweed was pretty decent too. We also decided to try their specials of the day: Scallop Burger and Kaisen Spoon. The spoon was good, however I couldn't taste the uni on the spoon, mostly oyster - but still tasted okay. The miso soup that came with the chirashi bowls were like any miso soup served in town and probably not homemade. The scallop burger was extremely tiny and was one piece of scallop cut in half to fit the uni and truffles. The truffle flavor overpowered the scallop and uni so I didn't realize the scallop was so sweet until I had it in my chirashi bowl. Not the best I've had, but decent.
author: Amanda C.

description: New place utilizing a small space very efficiently. Staff is nice and courteous, a good first impression. Simple dinner to enjoy, would definitely come again!  The ingredients all tasted fresh and the rice was cooked well. Yes, rice was cooked well, cooking rice is art. I like it a certain way, not too soft and not too hard. Maybe some alcohol in the future? LoL hopefully the city will allow them :) haha I'll enjoy sprite in the meantime here, or some tea.
author: Jeffrey W.

description: This is place is overrated. I ordered two bowl and it was already $70. Rice has too much vinegar in it. Fish was not that fresh. Picture looks really good though. However the taste is not the best. I would've eaten in a nice restaurant if I were going to pay that price.
author: Donna D.

description:
Picked up some dinner here a couple weeks ago. Small place with a couple of tables, probably seats around 15 people. The inside is nice and clean albeit a little plain. I ordered takeout for my girlfriend and I though since it was a cold night and I wanted to get home quickly to watch the Warriors game. The guy who took our takeout order was nice and gave us ample time to pick what we wanted.

I don't 100% remember what she ordered but I believe it was the Kaisen Don #1 and I ordered the Rainbow Don. The fish was very fresh but unfortunately, the portions don't match the price. My girlfriend gets full pretty easily but she ended up still being slightly hungry. Personally, I think I might have needed two to fill me up. It's about 3 pieces of each fish in the don. I know in order for them to have premium fish quality, they have to charge higher than other places but the prices are still too high. For this specific order, I still ended up spending around $30, even with the 20% discount they offered. I don't think I could fathom the thought of coming here without that discount. It honestly had me craving some Poki Time at Westlake just because the fish portion at Kaisen Don just wasn't enough.

I'm hoping that Kaisen Don can turn it around though. They have a great product but the prices are just too steep. I wish them the best!
author: R C.

description: I ordered the Rainbow Don and asked if I can replace one of the item with something else since I'm not a fan of tuna. They were very flexible with my request, so I got more salmon and hamachi. The fish were absolutely fresh and thick--just how I like it! The rice was perfectly cook. Their miso soup was good as well, not salty like most places. We also ordered the Uni Special, it was so fresh literally melted in my mouth. Will definitely come back for more.
author: Mimi Y.

description: Everything was fresh and very tasty.  Great presentation of the sashimi.  The kids loved their Unagi Don and Chashu Don.  Nice service and casual atmosphere.  Parking in the area is also easy which is a plus.  Will come again.
author: Michael C.

description: Went there for lunch and we were seated  right away. Its a new place so its very clean. The service was good and very welcoming. We ordered Omasake and Rainbow Don. The fish are very fresh and rice is well prepped. We also order the Hamachi Karma but was a bit undercook, which we sent back to get it steamed. I would say its bit on the pricy side, but you get good quality fish and food.
author: Jeff L.

description: FRESH & on point! This new establishment in the Ingleside neighborhood is mind blowing! It might seem like all the other poke bowl places; yet, it's completely different. Their chirashi bowl is so refreshing, not too saucy. With the seaweed they serve on the side, you get to personalize the way you eat your fish. Give it a try, and you'll be hooked
author: Zee Z.

description: Very impressed with the quality of the fish! We ordered a Kaisen Don #1, Hamachi don and a rainbow don. Fish were fresh and nice portion. I like how they serve the seaweed on a side and I can assemble my own sushi roll. I will definitely come back again to try other don!
author: Vic L.

description: Love this place! This is our go to Japanese place. We did noticed that the portions have gotten smaller which bums me out. We usually get the rainbow don, tuna don, chirashi and gyu-don.
author: Joy S.

description: My son and I ate here and had a great meal. The space is small so I wouldn't bring a large group.  The restaurant was very clean and the service was professional. They offer a variety of proteins on rice.  The raw fish wash fresh and nicely presented.  The uní don had a very generous portion of ikura.  Hot tea was graciously included.  They also offer several bowls with cooked meat for those not eating raw fish.  Vegetarian options were also offered.
author: Kat M.

description: Kaisen Don has good Donburi. The  fish  is fresh and the rice is good. We went on a weekday and it wasn't crowded. The staff is also very friendly and took their time explaining the menu. A little pricey, but worth it for fresh seafood.
author: Wilson W.

description: The fish is so fresh.  I hope they keep the quality of the fish up because that is key.  The high prices are worth it as long as the quality stays where it has been. I recommend the Rainbow Don
author: John G.

description: Had the salmon ochazuke. The cooking could be improved; but in general, had a great experience and I'm glad to have this eatery here in the neighborhood :)
author: Tianyi Y.

description: Best chirashi bowl I've had in my life!! Get the omakase bowl it is amazing value. Somehow tastes even better than it looks.
author: Jessica S.

description: An fine option for don in the neighborhood. Limited menu so seems like the kitchen is limited too. Quality of sashimi was good. Although unfortunately on the pricey side.
author: Heather R.

description: Their dons are decent and sashimi tasted fresh.  I liked how they brought us some fresh seaweed as well. The portion is just right for me, but the price is a little on the high end.
author: Joey K.

description:
Fresh, modern and simple. Stumbled onto this spot when I was craving sushi. More expensive than I would've liked, but totally worth it! 

For sure going again soon!
author: Melanie R.

description:
Here's another review hoping that Kaisen Don steps up it's rice game. 

It's unfortunate that with most sushi restaurants, rice is an afterthought and the fish is main attraction when it should be entirely the other way around. The rice at Kaisen Don was close to a good texture but slightly too wet and mushy, and completely lacked in any flavor whatsoever. No signs of sushi-su or sweetness and it ended up completely bland, reminding me of plain white porridge, which is really unfortunate because this place seems promising.

The fish, while not the best, was portioned very reasonably for the price. The nori provided was the highlight for me, I only wish that they provided a small dish to put them somewhere. I had to place them awkwardly on top of my don bowl as I ate, and ended up moving them onto my napkin.

Overall, I'm looking forward to giving this place another try in the future.
author: Mack S.

description:
Yes, the portions are fresh. No, the bowls are not as big as portrayed on Yelp (slightly bigger than a miso soup bowl).

Nonetheless, I was impressed by the freshness of this place. We tried the scallops and uni bowl / ikura bowl. Scallops and ikura were sweet and fresh without any aftertaste. The uni was on the tinier side but very fresh as well.

I recommend to try this place, but have some snacks first.
author: Steph C.

description:
I would request a bigger menu.  They basically only have maybe four or five chirashi bowls and beef curry which was the only hot dish.

I think they're new to the restaurant business as they lacked finesse.  We had to ask for utensils and then were surprised when they brought out cheap plastic spoons.  Waiter would bring out one dish at a time and then go to other tables to bring out their dishes (those customers came after us).  By the time the last person in our party got her dish, everyone had been sitting around for 10 to 15 minutes to start eating to be polite.  And everyone ordered the same thing but one person who ordered the curry.  According to that person, the curry tasted like it came right out of a box with barely any beef in the dish.

The staff was very nice though.  I think for what is offered and for the area, the menu prices are high for such a simple establishment.
author: Bea Q.

description: Great local spot. Very fresh fish. Good service. I enjoyed my meal there and will return and now just trying to hit the word quota.
author: R M.

description: Amazing fresh don bowl.  I'm not sure why some people says the rice is bland but I love the rice here - soft and chewy.  Maybe I came at good time?
author: Nara S.

description: Yum! Reminds me of the little mom and pop shops in Japan. The scallops and uni were sweet and served at the perfect temperature. Portions are huge. The salmon ochazuke needed a little bit of soy sauce but it was the perfect comfort food for rainy SF weather. I will be back (and bringing friends!) to try their sashimi.
author: Alice C.

description: Terrific fresh fish.  Great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Andrew N.

description:
Small place, but my good friend recommended me.  I love Japanese food, sushi, sashimi, ramen, udon.. all my favorites.  I even have an Japanese cuisine expert showing me the good stuff in SF and elsewhere in the world.  I don't claim to be "the expert", but I certainly do enjoy food.  When I go to Japanese restaurants, I do scan the menu for chirashi bowls.  I love sushi rice and sashimi.  You can pair the right of rice with your fish, and I pick my favorite flavor of fish.  When I heard that there's a new place that specializes Chirashi, I was super excited.  

At a glance, the place is small, looks modern, somewhat resembles bubble tea/fast food restaurant.  Dinning room seats small amount of guests, this is probably due to SF regulations.  Things looks very clean and sterile.  When I walked it, around 5:40pm, it wasn't so busy, but I realized there was a line outside the door about 15 minutes after i sat down.  

I was brought a menu with very nice pictures.  Not too much choices as a regular Japanese restaurant, but enough choices.  There are the scallop lover, Hamachi love, blue blue fin tuna, and even uni or toro.  The prices to me compare to many Japanese restaurants' Chirashi bowls are rather reasonable.  Usually, the Chirashi in a regular Japanese place is about 25 bucks above.  You can get the same less than 20 plus a 20% yelp discount - that is a deal.

I brought my family there, my wife and two kids.  We ordered a box of uni for appetizer.  My wife ordered the Rainbow bowl, and I ordered the hamachi bowl.  I ordered the thin slice beef bowl for my kids to share.  The bowls came up rather quickly, but not all at once.  They were well presented.  The chef did really take a lot of time making sure the bowls presentable.  The fish are very fresh and high quality.  I enjoyed every bite of my Kaisen Don.  

While I was there, I was able to located the owner, Larry.  While the places wasn't too busy, he told me about where he learned how to make chirashi bowls.  He basically like me who love chirashi.  He also recommended me to mix and match your chirashi bowls, and don't have to pick from the menu.

I did read Chris' review, and I appreciate him pointing out how Larry's chirashi isn't the perfect chirashi for him.  Perhaps Larry can learn something from his review.  For me, I am pretty satisfy with mine, or Larry's representation.  I feel that if everyone's chirashi is exactly the same, there won't be any innovation in food.  We will eat the same thing for hundreds of years, but perhaps someone like Chris will enjoy that, and there is nothing wrong with that.  Larry is certainly someone who will probably take advice from his toughest critics.  If not, how else would you make your customers happy.  5 stars for my experience.  Thank you Larry.
author: Dennis L.

description: Went here for their soft opening. They had 20% off. The fish is alright. The portions aren't too huge so it's not like you will stuffed. I got the Rainbow Don and had approximately 9-10 pieces of fish and some ikura sprinkled on top. Presentation is done really well. It's a tiny spot but nice for a neighborhood meal with a friend.
author: Jessica H.

description: This place is delicious! It's kind of everything I was looking for a sushi bowl! Fresh fish, decent price and generous portions .
author: Vlad S.

description:
The wait for Saturday lunch was short, about 5 mins. We ordered scallop lover and rainbow don. Food came with hot tea and hot miso soup (yums). 

Both dons came with a good amount of warm sushi rice. The presentation was beautiful (should've taken pictures but too hungry!) The fish and scallops were really fresh! No fishy taste or random chewy bits. The hot tea kept flowing throughout the meal. No complaints. 

For non raw fish eaters, they have a selection of cooked dons which looked equally as impressive.
author: Michelle T.

description:
The fish was ok and fresh which is good. I think everything is overpriced for the quality of the fish.

The worst was the sushi rice. It was just plain rice which is a big disappointment. It felt like I was just having a big bowl of white rice with some fish on top. The rice was missing the vinegar, sugar and salt. The basic ingredients that you will have in sushi rice. 

I ordered the rainbow don and added an amai ebi to my don. My amai ebi was really small and what made it worst is that my friend got the exact same thing as me, rainbow don with amai ebi but her amai ebi was a regular size. I was upset that I got a really small ebi but my friend got a regular size and she was sitting right next to me. We are paying for the same price, so how come my ebi was so small. They should just give us the same size or add another small amai ebi on my bowl to make it seem like all the portions of the rice bowls are the same. But they charged us $10 for two amai ebi. 

The place is really small and they had one server working. It wasn't really busy the day we went and the server was nice and he refilled our teas from time to time. 

Overall, I just feel like everything is overpriced even with the 20% off for soft opening.
author: Katie Y.

description: So far I've tried this place twice, first time for the scallop bowl and uni 1/2 tray, 2nd time for the unagi bowl. The quality of the seafood is rather average. The uni and scallops were rather bland for being usually one of the more flavorful sashimi you can get and the unagi was not any better than than a frozen eel you can get at a Japanese supermarket. Actually, the two poke places nearby this particular restaurant has better unagi than this place. They also give you miso soup with the donburi, which is nice, but it is also of average quality. The presentation of the food is very good, though, and would look quite nice if someone was doing it for the 'Gram. Overall, this place is OK.
author: Angela L.

description: This is my first time try out at this place. I am falling in love with this place. Food is exceed my expectations. Sashimi is extremely fresh. Price is very reasonable. I will come back again. Highly recommend this place.
author: Kathy M.

description: It's sosososososo good!! Nothing else I could say. Right now they are on soft opening，everything 20% off. It's definitely a good time to check out.
author: Xiaochen Z.

description: Ordered the unagi and chasu don, and my goodness were they delicious! The flavors are subtle, unlike other places' overwhelmingly sweet or salty versions. The owners were a sweet couple who gave us hot tea and miso soup while we waited for our food~ DEF coming back here whenever I'm back in the city! I just have to make it there at the right time cuz the space is quite cozy and gets filled up quickly!
author: Jasmine K.

description: I will definitely take the family here on a frequent basis. The sashimi was fresh. Generous portions at a reasonable price. Staff was very friendly and attentive.
author: Anna K.

description:
I live nearby, so I was happy to see this new addition to the neighborhood. 

The space is intimate and tastefully decorated, a quiet oasis on a busy stretch of Ocean. Complementary miso and tea was brought to the table quickly after I sat down. The fish was fresh and the rice perfectly cooked. The ikura were like little salty pearls. The little embossed wasabi puck was a cute touch. My very pleasant server, Larry, kept the tea flowing, welcome on this rainy day. Prices were fair for sushi fish. 

I'm told that the next iteration of their menu will have a vegetarian option, which my tamago and inari-loving kid will like. Her beer-loving dad hopes they get a liquor license, too. 

Welcome to the neighborhood, Kaisen-Don! Gambatte!
author: A P.

description: Amazng new Japanese Restaurant. I had the Curry Beef was delcious. My buddy had the Unagi and he loved it. We found this new place to eat and will be back. The staff is very nice. Leaving with smile.
author: Ron L.

description: What a great new restaurant on Ocean Ave! The best thing about this place is how fresh the sashimi tastes. No other Japanese restaurant in this area is on the same level. Prices are very reasonable for what you're getting. Also, the service is super friendly. My partner and I shared a Rainbow Don and a Beef Curry Don. Both were excellent. Each bowl also came with miso soup. Highly recommend and will be going back soon!
author: Garrett L.

description: Sorry, I'm going to disagree w/Michael re:reasonable prices. We paid $18.95 for ea of our bowls & felt that we didn't get much food. The service was ok..certainly not w/a smile, but was served in a reasonable amount of time. Our miso soup was lukewarm at best. Glad to have gotten a 20% discount for the soft opening, but I don't think this place is for me.
author: susan w.

description: Great food and service. Got seated promptly and the food came out very quickly too. Ordered the thin beef , Salmon and another dish. All three were good but the beef was the best.
author: Manoj Y.

description: Just stopped by here during their soft opening and I'm so glad that we have a decent sushi place in our neighborhood!  Hubby got the hamachi bowl--large slabs served with tamago, salmon roe and cucumber.  I got the rainbow don with tuna, hamachi, salmon and salmon roe.  The fish was fresh and the meal came with free tea and miso soup--nothing too special but nice on a chilly day.  The menu is pretty limited, with only sushi rice available as a base.  It sounds like they plan to add more choices in the future.  If the quality stays good we're looking forward to making this place a frequent stop for dinner.
author: Andrea K.

description: Really fresh ingredients. Good quality for price! Still soft opening so they gave us 20% discount. Would recommend.
author: Katrina W.

description: Overpriced for very small portions. The restaurant is extremely small and tiny there's not enough space for people to sit. Overall food was OK but not particularly fresh
author: Alex H.

description: Food is fresh, flavor right. One thing they could improve on is the rice. It was a little hard and not chewy.
author: Phuong P.

description: Good services. Tasty fish and fresh. Not bad for a quick healthy bite. Comfortable and clean feel restaurant even though is small.
author: Henry C.

description: Our table of 4 got seated right away on a Friday evening. The atmosphere is minimalist, not charming or comfortable. I would like more ambiance going out to eat at that price point (~$20/bowl). We tried 4 different bowls. Mine was scallop and uni from the specials board. The scallops were good, but it's a very small portion for $20.95. The uni was just two small pieces. It had ikura, which was not mentioned as part of the bowl. Unfortunately, I don't like ikura. We asked for the 20%, and at first they said that was over. We told them we saw it on Yelp and they asked us to show it to them. The Yelp mobile phone version doesn't mention the 20% discount, but the Yelp desktop version did that day (and still does 4 days later as I write this review). The servers were nice enough and eventually they said the manager would extend the 20% discount to us. Overall, we it was a very underwhelming experience and we will not return.
author: Jane M.
